A totative of a given positive integer \(m\) is an integer \(k\) such that \(0 \lt k \le m\) and \(k\) is coprime to \(m\). Euler's totient function \(\phi(m)\) counts the number of totatives of \(m\). For example, 2 and 7 are coprime to 15, so they are a totative of 15, and the number of totatives of 15 is \(\phi(15) = 8\).

Euler's Theorem: If \((a, m) = 1\), then \(a^{\phi(m)} ≡ 1 \bmod m\).

Fermat's Little Theorem: \(a^{p-1} ≡ 1 \bmod p \) for prime \(p\) and an integer \(a\).
From Euler's theorem, derive Fermat's little theorem.
Prove Euler's theorem. Hint: If \(\{r_1, \ldots, r_k\}\) is a reduced residue system of \(m\), then so is \(\{ar_1, \ldots, ar_k\}\), where \(a\) is coprime to \(m\).
Use Fermat's little theorem to find the least nonnegative residue modulo \(13\) of \(29^{202}\).

Fermat's Little Theorem: \(a^{p-1} ≡ 1 \bmod p \) for prime \(p\) and an integer \(a\). Let \(a=29\) and \(m=13\). We know that \(p \nmid a\), so:

$$ 29^{12} ≡ 1 \bmod 13 $$

Since \(202 = 12 (16) + 10\):

$$\begin{gather} 29^{12} ≡ 1 \bmod 13 \\ (29^{12})^{16} ≡ 1^{16} \bmod 13 \\ 29^{192} ≡ 1 \bmod 13 \end{gather}$$

Since \(29 ≡ 3 \bmod 13\):

$$\begin{gather} 29^{10} ≡ 3^{10} \bmod 13 \\ 3^{10} ≡ 59049 ≡ 3 \bmod 13 \end{gather}$$

This means:

$$\begin{gather} (29^{192})(29^{10}) ≡ (1)(3) \bmod 13 \\ (29^{202}) ≡ 3 \bmod 13 \end{gather}$$

Since \(11 \nmid 123\) and \(11 \nmid 456\), then we can use Fermat's little theorem here:

$$\begin{gather} 123^{10} ≡ 1 \bmod 11 \\ (123^{10})^{32} ≡ 1^{32} \bmod 11 \\ 123^{320} ≡ 1 \bmod 11 \\ 123^{320} * 123 ≡ 123 \bmod 11 \\ 123^{321} ≡ 2 \bmod 11 \end{gather}$$

Now let's focus on \(456^{654}\):

$$\begin{gather} 456^{10} ≡ 1 \bmod 11 \\ (456^{10})^{65} ≡ 1^{65} \bmod 11 \\ 456^{650} ≡ 1 \bmod 11 \end{gather}$$

Since \(456 ≡ 5 \bmod 11\):

$$\begin{gather} 456^4 ≡ 5^4 ≡ 625 ≡ 9 \bmod 11 \end{gather}$$

This means:

$$\begin{gather} 456^{650} * 456^4 ≡ 1*9 \bmod 11 \\ 456^{654} ≡ 9 \bmod 11 \end{gather}$$

Putting the two together:

$$\begin{align} 456^{654} + 123^{321} &≡ 9 + 2 \bmod 11 \\ &≡ 11 ≡ 0 \bmod 11 \end{align}$$
Let \(p\) and \(q\) be distinct prime numbers. Prove or disprove that \(p^{q-1} + q^{p-1} ≡ 1 \bmod pq\)

According to Fermat's little theorem:

$$\begin{align} q^{p-1} &≡ 1 \bmod p \\ q^{p-1} + p^{q-1} &≡ 1 + p^{q-1} \bmod p \end{align}$$

Diving \(1 + p^{q-1}\) by \(p\) will give a remainder of 1, so:

$$ q^{p-1} + p^{q-1} ≡ 1 \bmod p $$

Also according to Fermat's little theorem:

$$\begin{align} p^{q-1} &≡ 1 \bmod q \\ p^{q-1} + q^{p-1} ≡ 1 + q^{p-1} \bmod q \end{align}$$

Diving \(1 + q^{p-1}\) by \(q\) will give a remainder of 1, so:

$$ p^{q-1} + q^{p-1} ≡ 1 \bmod p $$

Since \((p,q)=1\):

$$ p^{q-1} + q^{p-1} ≡ 1 \bmod pq $$
Let \(a\) and \(b\) be integers not divisible by \(p\). Prove that if \(a^p ≡ b^p \bmod p\), then \(a ≡ b \bmod p\)

According to Fermat's little theorem:

$$\begin{align} a^{p-1} &≡ 1 \bmod p \\ b^{p-1} &≡ 1 \bmod p \end{align}$$

This means:

$$\begin{align} a^p &≡ a \bmod p \\ b^p &≡ b \bmod p \end{align}$$

This means if \(a^p ≡ b^p \bmod p\), then \(a ≡ b \bmod p\).
Let \(p\) and \(q\) be distinct odd primes such that \(p-1 | q-1\), and let there be an integer \(a\) such that \((a,pq)=1\). Prove or disprove that \(a^{q-1} ≡ 1 \bmod p\).

If \(p-1 | q-1\), then \((p-1)k = q-1\). If \((p,q)=1\) and \((a, pq)=1\), then \(1=(a,p)*(a,q)\), which means both \((a,p)\) and \((a,q)\) are 1.

According to Fermats little theorem:

$$ a^{p-1} ≡ 1 \bmod p $$

If we raise both sides to \(k\):

$$\begin{gather} (a^{(p-1)})^k ≡ 1^k \bmod p \\ a^{(p-1)k} ≡ a^{(q-1)} ≡ 1 \bmod p \end{gather}$$

Also according to Fermats little theorem:

$$ a^{q-1} ≡ 1 \bmod q $$

Since \(a^{q-1} ≡ 1 \bmod p\), \(a^{q-1} ≡ 1 \bmod p\) and \((p, q)=1\):

$$ a^{q-1} ≡ 1 \bmod pq $$
Let \(a\) be an integer and \(p\) be a prime integer. Prove that \(p|a^p + (p-1)!a\) and that \(p|a + (p-1)! a^p\).

If \(p|a\), then \(p|a^p + (p-1)!a\) and \(p|a + (p-1)! a^p\), as \(a\) can be factored out from \(a^p + (p-1)!a\) and \(a + (p-1)! a^p\).

If \(p \nmid a\), then by Fermat's little theorem:

$$\begin{gather} a^{p-1} ≡ 1 \bmod p \\ a^p ≡ a \bmod p \end{gather}$$

Wilson's theorem states:

$$ (p-1)! ≡ -1 \bmod p $$

If we multiply the two:

$$\begin{gather} (p-1)! a^p ≡ -a \bmod p \\ (p-1)! a^p +a ≡ 0 \bmod p \end{gather}$$

This proves that \(p|a + (p-1)! a^p\). If we multiply them a different way

$$\begin{gather} (p-1)! a ≡ -a^p \bmod p \\ (p-1)! a + a^p ≡ 0 \bmod p \end{gather}$$

This proves that \(p|a^p + (p-1)!a\).
